Another area of litigation that's going on
is in the area of security clearances.
Security clearances are necessary for people,
many people who work for the government
or work for private industry that do contracts with the government,
generally in the areas of energy and defense.
And what security clearance means is that
the government says that you are okay
to look at classified information,
to feel that you're not going to default this information.
There's different levels of security clearances.
Gay people over the years have had a great deal of problems
getting security clearances,
and what we've found is that the government's policy on this
is somewhat inconsistent.
They do not have an interagency plan
or set of guidelines or criteria.
Each agency decides on its own,
and there's an awful lot of discretion that can be exercised.
What we found is a recent trend where in many agencies
a person can get a security clearance.
Some agencies, so-called intelligence agencies,
I call them the police agencies, the FBI, the CIA,
the National Security Agency,
are hanging in there tough,
and they will not grant security clearances
to anybody that they know is gay.
There's been some recent litigation against the CIA.
There's one case that was filed more than a year ago
in the District of Columbia district,
it's before Judge Barrington-Parker,
and he's been sitting on motions for summary judgment
in that case for more than a year now.
There was a recent case filed in Los Angeles,
the U.S. District Court down there,
involving John Green, who was an engineer
with a company known as TRW.
He's worked for TRW, I believe, for 13 years,
and he's never had any problems.
The CIA, in fact, has never said
that he leaked anything
or any information or divulged any information,
but basically what they said was that he was gay
and that he was subject to blackmail when he was gay,
and therefore might divulge information.
So that argument breaks down when the person says,
I'm not subject to blackmail,
I'm open about my sexuality, my family knows,
my friends know, there's no big deal to me,
I don't know why it's a big deal to you,
but to the CIA it's still a big deal,
and they just cannot understand
why there might be some kind of
or might not be some kind of problem here.
So that case is pending the U.S. District Court.
The government just yesterday filed this brief,
they filed a motion to dismiss.
They said the court lacked jurisdiction to hear the case
based on solemn immunity.
They said the government would not consent
to be sued in this case.
And they also said that the judiciary
would be infringing on the executive branch of government
by getting involved in this matter.
They said the CIA had absolute discretion
to decide who gets the security clearance
and who does not.
So they will be responsible for filing that on March 2nd.
I'll talk only about two more issues.
One is briefly some First Amendment cases
that we're involved in.
We find that a number of gay community newspapers
like here in San Francisco, we have the Bay Area Reporter,
are being censored at a number of prisons around the country.
Prisons that want to keep in touch with their gay communities
are not being allowed to read these papers.
So we're going to be involved in a suit probably
at, if we're lucky, the Congressional Correctional Institute
in Kentucky and maybe one here at the Lompoc Prison
and possibly one down in Texas as well.
And then the last thing that I want to talk about
is the rights of gay students.
I went to, well, I went to several undergraduate schools.
I graduated from Michigan State University,
which is where I first got involved in gay political causes.
And as a student, I brought a suit against the university
for refusing to allow us to place a banner
on the two official posts, shall we say,
of the university where you can announce events.
And Michigan State University is on a main thoroughfare
with 40,000 cars a day past students' intersections.
We wanted to put a banner that said Gay Pride Week
and the administration wouldn't let us.
So we filed an action against the university.
We didn't win, but it was probably because
we weren't adequately prepared because we found out
from sort of some of our sources post-administration
that they had been warned by their lawyers
not to do that again next year
because they were probably in some pretty serious trouble.
And so the next year, we made an application
to put up the banner and we ended up without any problems.
Now this same school, sitting in a city
that has an anti-discrimination ordinance,
which I helped lobby for in 1971,
last year they allowed that gay students
be kicked out of fraternities simply because they were gay.
So even though you have an anti-discrimination ordinance,
it's not going to be worth a whole lot
and it's not enforced.
So there are continuing problems going on.
We found that there's a school, another school mission
called Andrews College, which is trying to kick out
two students because they allege they're gay.
There's a private college in the suburb of Chicago
that once ran a bachelor's degree to a student
who's completed all of his coursework
and said this person's gay and doesn't meet
the criminal character requirements of our schools
and he can't handle his degree.
We find that the University of Arkansas in Batesville,
the school has granted official university recognition
to the student organization there,
but they won't grant them any office space
or any funding or any other benefits
that might go along with official recognition.
There's two cases going on in Texas right now
involving the rights of students to get recognition
at their campus and my last big gay rights case
before I came to the West Coast
involved the lawsuit against Georgetown University
in Washington, D.C. because they would not grant recognition
to the undergraduate into the law school
gay student organizations.
So there are still a lot of lawsuits involved
against students as well as many other areas
that are important.
We can become complacent here in California.
It doesn't have a sodomy statute anymore.
We have a lot of protections.
People to a great extent are maybe a lot more relaxed.
They're used to hearing about seeing a gay community
as sort of this old hat.
But in most parts of the country,
there's still a lot of problems.
And that's what National Gay Rights Advocates
is all about.
It's writing these new laws about diversity in the country.
Is Gay Rights Advocates taking on any cases
involving gay youth and their rights to their sexuality
if they have not reached any consent?
Because that seems to be something in California
that is sort of an issue.
And it's very difficult to consider.
Yeah, there's a lot of problems
in that area.
We have not taken on any cases involving that issue.
I can't say we've been presented with any.
What we do in determining what cases to take
is we basically wait for people to come to us,
which is not much of a problem.
I get calls every day.
If a day doesn't go by,
they don't get at least one call,
so I'm not concerned about some kind of discrimination
or adverse action.
But that particular issue hasn't reached us yet.
What you do talk about is in housing,
screenwriters have been pointing out
that this city, Denver,
has a law that says two unrelated individuals
cannot live together.
And this is often against gay couples.
What's the status of those?
And has anything been done about it?
We haven't had any complaints in a long time
about that kind of problem.
That is a way of certainly discriminating
against gay people.
Without being so forthright as saying
that we're not going to allow two gay people
to live together.
The history of that kind of legislation,
I'm not so sure was necessarily anti-gay,
but was intended to keep noise down
and to protect sort of family-type environments.
But it certainly can have an impact on gay people.
In some areas like that,
it's very subtle with legislation.
In some states like Virginia,
it's very blatant.
But it's very subtle.
Thank you.
Thank you.
